title: Identifying the Influential Bloggers

author: Nitin Agarwal, Department of Information Science, Donaghey College of Engineering and Information Technology, University of Arkansas at Little Rock

segmentation: In this talk I'll introduce the problem.

Past 15 years computers and Internet have revolutionized the communication.
People can connect with each other across different time zones with all geographical barriers and this has created a humongous mesh of social interactions which people call a social network.

As you can see in the illustration, there are different services which revolve around Web 2.0 paradigm, which has basically catalyzed this communication, and by the ease of use interface and desktop like experience, these services like friendship, networks, blogs, wikis, collaborative tagging and media sharing.
In our research, we focus on blogsphere.
Block sites could be individual or community for individual blog sites.
These are owned and maintained by individual users as compared to community block sites, which are owned and maintained by a group of like minded users.
And community block sites are more like discussion forums and discussion boards where you can see high degree of group discussion and collaboration, whereas an individual block sides.
They're more like personal accounts, journals or Diaries.
An almost negligible group interaction is there.
